QUOTE OF THE DAY"Some people never go crazy. 
      What truly horrible lives they must lead." - Charles Bukowski 


DID YOU KNOW?Frank Baum named "Oz" after a file cabinet 
      in his office. One cabinet was labeled "A to N," and the second was 
      labeled "O to Z." 
      
TONIGHT ON THE CBS 
      EVENING NEWSHere is an early preview of what we 
      are planning for tonight's CBS EVENING NEWS from Anchor and Managing 
      Editor, Katie Couric... Hi everyone, Tonight, 
      we'll be broadcasting from Philadelphia, home of the Independence Hall, 
      the Liberty Bell and a vibrant population that is the sixth-largest in the 
      United States. Philly is also known as the city where American democracy 
      was born - and tonight we'll have a cultural and historical view of a city 
      that has contributed so much to our country's history. This city, 
      which was home to the country's first hospital - founded by Benjamin 
      Franklin in 1751 - now is having a health-care crunch that's particularly 
      acute for pregnant women and the care they're getting when it counts. 
      I'll take a closer look at this story for you. Before that, 
      the news of the day. To start out our broadcast, David Martin will 
      have an exclusive report on Pentagon planning and the war in Iraq. 
      Meanwhile, are Democrats blinking first on the prospect of a withdrawal 
      deadline? Sharyl Attkisson will fill you in. A different 
      kind of debate is heating up on the streets - and on the Web. An 
      anti-informant "stop snitching" campaign now has a high-tech edge. And 
      this is infuriating federal prosecutors, Bob Orr will explain. 
      As hurricane season approaches, National Weather Service 
      forecasters warn that they expect between 13 and 17 tropical storms this 
      year, with at least seven of them becoming hurricanes. Is the Gulf Coast 
      ready? Hari Sreenivasan will examine New Orleans' levee system and 
      whether it is equipped to survive a major storm. We've been 
      following the story of the two whales stranded 60 miles up the Sacramento 
      River in California. Sandra Hughes will tell you about the 
      obstacles still in their way en route to their ocean home - and the hope 
      spectators have for their safe return. Finally, we'll come back to 
      Philadelphia, where we will settle down with a cheese steak and channel 
      some memories from decades past in the City of Brotherly Love. 
      I hope you'll join us. Katie For 
      more information on these stories, please click on the following 
      links: Dems Back Off Deadline For Troop Pullout
Click Here Experts Predict 
      Active Hurricane Season Click Here And here's a look at 
      one of the stories we're working on for Wednesday's broadcast:
Starting Wednesday, a two-part look at "Insurance Outrage"... Some 
      people just can't GET coverage, while others HAVE it until they really 
      NEED it. This story and much more, Wednesday, on the CBS Evening 
      News. If you would like more 
      information on the broadcast, please click on the following address and 
      e-mail us: evening@cbsnews.com 

TONIGHT ON DAVID 
      LETTERMANNBA commentator/basketball legend Charles Barkley 
      joins Dave tonight along with actor Seth Rogen... Plus, musical 
      guest Michael Martin Murphey! 

WEDNESDAY MORNING ON THE 
      EARLY SHOWHarry Smith, Hannah 
      Storm, Julie Chen and Russ Mitchell anchor THE 
      EARLY SHOW from New York. Dave Price 
      will bring us the weather. Along with the top news of the day, 
      we will also have the following stories: CELLULITE 
      SOLUTIONS: Why do women get cellulite and men don't? Well, you can 
      blame estrogen. But there is hope! If you have cellulite, you know all 
      about trying to hide it. But now some new treatments on the market may 
      help it go away. EARLY SHOW Consumer 
      Correspondent Susan Koeppen will join us with the news every woman 
      wants to hear -- "How to get rid of that cellulite." HAPPILY 
      EVER AFTER, PART 3: Our special series, Happily Ever After, 
      continues Wednesday morning with an incredible story of love and 
      parenting. The Luchsingers met in college, married after graduation and 
      are now dealing with the challenge of three children, one of whom is 
      autistic. For Kadi and Todd, like all parents, they have to balance taking 
      care of their kids with all of life's other demands. Nearly 85% of parents 
      with special needs children end up divorcing... but Kadi and Todd are 
      battling the odds and making it work. MONEY MATTERS: STUDENT 
      LOANS: Getting a loan to help pay for college is nothing new. But 
      there are certain things you should look out for before you, or your 
      child, signs on that dotted line. How can you choose an offer that will 
      leave you worry free? Our financial advisor Ray Martin will join us 
      with tips on what to look for in a student loan. BEST YOU CAN 
      BE: SUMMER BATHING SUITS: Summer is just a few weeks away and for many 
      of us, that means time spent poolside and at the beach! But dreaded 
      bathing suit season comes with its pitfalls. How can you find a suit that 
      both fits and flatters? Style expert Rachael Zalis will help you find the 
      best suit for your body as swimsuit season gets underway. SUSAN 
      CRANDELL: THINKING ABOUT TOMORROW: You have probably heard the term 
      midlife crisis. It typically refers to the time when a person in their 
      forties and fifties realize that they are no longer young and start to 
      feel that perhaps they haven't really lived. In her new book, Thinking 
      About Tomorrow: Reinventing Your Midlife, author Susan Crandell tells 
      us how you can fulfill dreams that you may have been holding on to or how 
      you can create new ones in your middle years. Wednesday morning, Crandell 
      will join us with her advice. If you would like more information 
      on any of these stories or the broadcast, please click on the following 
      address and e-mail us: earlyshow@cbs.com
